awd_titl_txt: Western Alliance to Expand Student Opportunities (WAESO) to Parity Capstone Operational, Research, Evaluation, Documentation and Institutionalization 10+ LSAMP Alliance
awd_abstract_narration:
This long-standing LSAMP activity was designed to support a strong and vibrant scientific and technological workforce through recruiting, retaining, and graduating scientists and engineers from currently underrepresented populations. The WASEO Alliance (one of the first projects sponsored by NSF?s Louis Stokes Alliances for Minority Participation) utilizes a multi-contextual approach involving project activities in student research experiences, the establishment of peer networks, an emphasis on the social context of science, and development of a culture of professionalism in students, to name a few areas. This multi-contextual approach will be tested scientifically and documented for scaling up nation-wide in order to continue our drive to increase the number of B.S. degrees earned annually by underrepresented minority science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) students.  The project, in its final five years of NSF support (2016-2021), will seek to increase graduation rates in Arizona and Utah such that Alliance institutions will represent 33.8% of total bachelor?s degrees to minority STEM students in Arizona and Utah.  That percentage would be roughly equal to today?s percentage of underrepresented minorities in the general population of those states. 

The WAESO and its 13 Alliance partner institutions will continue to make improvements to its innovative research, teaching, and academic support interventions on behalf of undergraduate minority STEM students.  These support interventions have been developed over the past 24 years and rated highly by external evaluation. In a very significant new addition, WAESO will initiate a major knowledge-generating, social science educational research project to scientifically study, test and evaluate the multi-contextual elements at work in order to determine their positive impacts on student advancement and faculty culture.  The results of this research will contribute to our understanding of the positive changes in WAESO institutions as a result of the LSAMP program; and how the program components of the WAESO LSAMP lead to minority STEM student success.  Project outcomes will, in turn, point the way toward a successful scaling of these best practices to a regional and national level.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
Broad Goals

The broad goals of the Western Alliance to Expand Student Opportunities (WAESO) program were: 

  • To improve underrepresented minority (URM) science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) student annual bachelor of science graduation at WAESO institutions as compared with the URM general populations. 
  • To scientifically determine, research, test, and evaluate the elements that have been contributing to the success of the WAESO students and programs.

The WAESO institutions spanned three states (Arizona, Colorado, and Utah), and included the following institutions in Arizona:  Arizona State University (Lead), University of Arizona, Chandler Gilbert Community College, Estrella Mountain Community College, Gateway Community College, Glendale Community College,  Phoenix College, South Mountain Community College ; in Colorado: Regis University; in Utah: Brigham Young University, University of Utah, and Utah Valley University.

 

Outcomes

Intellectual Merit of WAESO 

The WAESO project consisted of a series of activities that can be divided into three broad categories of (1) improving STEM Knowledge, (2) preparing students for graduate school, and (3) social science research. To improve STEM knowledge, Peer Study Groups and Summer Bridge Programs were funded. Faculty directed undergraduate research programs, research presentations, and workshops were the primary activities that were used to prepare students for graduate school. The social science research component of the project consisted of training both students and faculty in the principles of Multicontext Theory (MCT) so that participants could be more aware of and perhaps intentionally tap into MCT to achieve success.

There are multiple notable outcomes from the funded project. In the 2016-2022 timeframe:

  • 1476 total students directly engaged within WAESO, with 71% Hispanic/Latinx;
  • 677 research presentations were made by WAESO students;
  • 352 awards were earned by WAESO students;
  • over 83 publications that include WAESO students were published; and
  • 62 new faculty mentors participated in WAESO.

Additional analyses of WAESO research activities showed that the majority of student participants majored in the life and biological sciences as well as in the engineering fields. The Geosciences field was the least represented major within WAESO. 

 

Broader Impacts of WAESO 

STEM Bachelor of Science degrees awarded annually to underrepresented minorities at WAESO participating institutions increased by 71.4% from the baseline at the start of the grant (i.e. from 2170 to 3720). STEM Masters degrees awarded annually to underrepresented minorities at WAESO participating institutions increased by 133% from the baseline at the start of the grant (i.e. from 287 to 671). These increased numbers of awarded degrees met and exceeded the proposed targets as set forth in the original WAESO proposal for this cycle. The increased graduation rates point to successful institutional efforts that were undertaken by WAESO partners to diversify STEM. 

 

The faculty-driven research efforts that were undertaken within WAESO helped to improve students' involvement and persistence in STEM. Through a rigorous evaluation process, it was determined that students' confidence improved by the process that WAESO utilized of having faculty recruit students into their research programs, rather than having students initiate the contact. 

 

By providing students and faculty with training in the social science construct of Multicontext theory, WAESO helped to improve the academic system and how individuals navigated and helped to change the system. Papers were written and conference presentations given regarding Multicontext Theory (as just one example, see Weissmann, G.S.; Ibarra, R.A.; Howland-Davis, M.; Lammey,M.V. The Multicontext Path to Redefining How We Access and Think about Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion in STEM. J Geosci. Educ. 2019, 67, 320-329).

 

Areas for Further Growth

Additional efforts are needed in more broadly disseminating the social science component of the WAESO program.  Specifically, more work is needed to fully activate Multicontext Theory in intentional ways. The intentional activation of Multicontext Theory will help in the institutionalization of efforts to broaden participation, while also helping to propel the next generation of STEM leaders into additional trailblazing STEM accomplishments.  

 

 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 01/22/2023
Modified by: Jean M Andino
